title: ASIA MARKETS: Asian Markets Gain On Trade Hopes After Data Shows China's Exports Slump
text:
By Marketwatch and Associated Press

Nikkei, Shanghai indexes edge up; Hang Seng stays about flat

Asian markets were generally higher in early trading Monday, as investors continued to digest recent economic data from the U.S. and China.

On Sunday, a new report showed (link)China's trade with the U.S dropped sharply in August, as new tariffs by both sides were announced. Imports of American goods tumbled 22% in August from a year earlier to $10.3 billion, customs data showed Sunday, according to the Associated Press. Exports to the United States, China's biggest market, sank 16% to $44.4 billion.

More tariffs went into effect on Sept. 1, and the next round of tariffs on Chinese goods is scheduled to take effect Oct. 15. Last week, the U.S. and China said they have agreed to renew trade negotiations in early October.

Japan's Nikkei rose 0.4% while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index slipped 0.1%, as pro-democracy protests continued (link)over the weekend. The Shanghai Composite gained 0.4% and the smaller-cap Shenzhen Composite advanced 0.8%. South Korea's Kospi rose 0.6%, while benchmark indexes in Taiwan , Singapore and Indonesia made slight gains. Australia's S&P/ASX 200 edged up 0.1%.

Among individual stocks, convenience-store chain FamilyMart (8028.TO) rose in Tokyo trading, as did telecom company NTT Docomo (9437.TO) , while SoftBank (9984.TO) fell. In Hong Kong, PetroChina (601857.SH) and Sunny Optical (2382.HK) gained, while property developers such as New World (0017.HK) sank. Samsung (005930.SE) advanced in South Korea, while Beach Energy (BPT.AU) declined in Australia.

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

September 08, 2019 22:45 ET (02:45 GMT)
